title: Will there be an act of domestic terrorism in the United States resulting in 10 or more fatalities before 1 January 2022?
preds: Maybe now that they’ve all unwrapped the Confederate flags they got for Christmas they’re ready to strike. Any minute now.
The tens of millions of right wing terrorists in the United States are really sitting on their hands these days.
There is a long of BLM and civil unrest that will play in the domestic terror threat. With several high profile jury trials closing by EOY that may enable a terrorist act to transpire.

Direct update of my previous (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1319581) forecast gives 2.9...% Revise downward because it's nearly the end of the year. Schools and offices will have even fewer folks in them, so there're fewer targets. Plus, there was only one attack in December (out of 6) in @SpecialMatt 's list of events (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1277258) that may count. (1:5) * (1:33) = 1:165 < 1%.

I wonder whether the bar has quietly shifted in recent years to make it much harder for things to be classified as terrorism.
10 fatilities seems quite a few. I guess holiday season might be a target. But nothing I can see over Thanksgiving.
Reducing probability for the passage of time.

Fiery, dramatic incidents tend to be salient in people's minds, so a crowd of people will always overestimate rare events like this, even in a place like GJOpen which is a lot more rational than the general population. We should be a lot more afraid of cars than terrorism, yet that's not how our brains work. https://www.cdc.gov/injury/features/global-road-safety/index.html

Base:  Using 3/9 years that have had more than 10 fatalities.  4/12 months remaining = 11%.   Other factors: Dropping 4% for being during a pandemic.  (less targets, less agitation for perpetrators)
I think the consensus forecast is over confident by more than half.

Despite wishing otherwise, I believe there will be such an act.
See:  CSIS report and data (https://www.csis.org/analysis/military-police-and-rise-terrorism-united-states).  In 2020, the number of domestic terrorist attacks and plots increased to its highest level since at least 1994, though fatalities were relatively low. Across all perpetrator ideologies, there were 110 domestic terrorist attacks and plots in 2020—an increase of 45 incidents since 2019 and 40 more incidents than in 2017, the year which previously had the most terrorist attacks and plots since the beginning of the data set. Despite this sharp increase in terrorist activity, the number of fatalities from domestic terrorist attacks was at its lowest level since 2013. Five people were killed in terrorist attacks in 2020—an 86 percent decrease from 2019, when 35 individuals died in terrorist attacks.

Passage of time. The news media are currently splashing headlines about a nut who was caught outside the US Capitol today, making this low-probability outcome salient in people's minds again. The odds of San Francisco having a 7.0 or higher earthquake is something like 3% a year. People who are considering moving there will tend to overweight the possibility of it happening in the next year. People who have lived in SF for awhile tend to underestimate it ("I've lived here for X years and everything has been fine!")
Active terrorist threat outside the Capitol today. Area being evacuated, ongoing active negotiation with suspect.

updating for time elapsed. I still like my base rate as well as any I've seen or thought of, and although the news makes it seem like things are getting crazier than normal, I don't think they are any crazier than when I made my initial forecast.  I think it is important to realize that this is a two part question. 1) will an event occur that causes 10 or more fatalities before 1 Jan 2022 and 2) will that event be labeled domestic terrorism.  Part 2 is tricky to forecast because terrorism is a political label for a specific type of crime, it's easier to predict a crime rate than to predict how policy makers will react to a specific criminal act.
Revising downward due to the passage of time.
They only have twenty-six minutes to overthrow the government and reinstall Trump as president! They better hurry up!

August 13 is only two days away! And the plethora of three-initialed Federal law enforcement agencies are no doubt preparing for an uprising of meth-mouthed, gun totin' Trump supporters who will bust out with the worst spasm of violence since the St. Bartholomew's Day Massacre, or maybe the Sicilian Vespers. And then when nothing happens, they'll say, "Just wait until the next random date that we're dreading for no reason we can actually identify..." Whereupon the cycle will begin again, with Business Insider quoting unnamed "domestic terrorism analysts," and a new spate of links posted on this thread.

Base rate from @hoosier2020 and @nadie708 is roughly 35%. That means the "daily" p ≈ 0.00117953097320931... There are 144 days until 2022-01-01, so we use 1 - (1 - p)^144 ≈ 15.6%. Crowd is 15%, so that's my base rate (3:17 as odds). I *want* to push this down, but I don't feel that's justified. As states open up, eviction moratoriums end, COVID-19 support funds stop, etc. folks who live close to the edge may lose their jobs. That *might* be an instigator for terrorism. On the other hand, public health restrictions are easing too, so that might reduce right-wing efforts to force governors to "open up". Others, e.g. @SpecialMatt, have given base rates between 20% and 40%. These are symmetrical about 35% and both have reasonable grounding.  All that is to say I have no clear argument for moving from 15%... https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1231000 -- hoosier202 comment with base rate
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1232017 -- nadie708 comment with base rate
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1277258 -- SpecialMatt comment with base rate

True domestic terrorism (accounting for an actual plan and motive) is unlikely. Mass shootings happen every single weekend in major cities around the country, though often with fewer than 10 deaths from a single event, and those aren't considered terrorism. The FBI's involvement in spurring on terroristic events has been in focus for the past 18+ years, up to and including current events. First in the case of local 'islamic terrorism' and now in this dubious branding shift to 'domestic/white' terrorism. Journalists have shown how nearly all the covered events involved FBI contact before, or just immediately prior via undercover assets. In numerous cases the person had a mental illness, was low IQ, or similar.  The only thing that muddies the water for my prediction is what will be deemed domestic terrorism. Could a workplace shooting happen that kills up to 10 people in a single event? It could. Would the motive clearly be domestic terrorism or a bitter psychotic running amok? Would it involve heavy FBI contact beforehand?
Revising downward for the passage of time.

Again, the question isn't any more whether or not there will be an act of domestic terrorism - one only needs to watch the news to see that there are plenty of people planning such acts - but whether or not such an act will succeed and murder 10 or more people.
Americans overestimate terrorism chances and I hope I am one of them.

The Availability Heuristic is causing the Crowd to assign too high a probability:
https://www.thecut.com/2017/01/why-americans-are-so-scared-of-terrorism.html
>Americans are over 3,000 times more likely to be killed by a firearm than by terrorism. But the psychology is not so simple: Despite those stats, “terrorist attack on nation” and “victim of terrorism” both rank among the top five of Americans’ greatest fears, according to the 2016 edition of Chapman University’s Survey of American Fears.  Vivid examples come to mind when thinking about how this thing may resolve positively, and it's hard to imagine that in fact this is a low probability. Reminder that mass shootings happen all the time in the US, except that almost always they are standard criminal/gangland shootings rather than terrorism: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mass_shootings_in_the_United_States_in_2021
Just on July 5th for example, there were 12 casualties at a block-party shooting in Toledo: https://www.toledoblade.com/local/police-fire/2021/07/05/toledo-police-chief-george-kral-news-conference-shooting-block-party/stories/20210705114

- issues such as immigration and climate change could be problematic. https://www.dhs.gov/ntas/advisory/national-terrorism-advisory-system-bulletin-january-27-2021

The FBI reclassified the 2017 Repubican baseball shooting as 'an act of domestic terror'. Since this reclassification took 4 years, I no longer think it likely that the March 2021 mass shooting will be reclassified to 'an act of domestic terror' before 01JAN2021.
https://thehill.com/policy/national-security/553958-fbi-reclassifies-2017-baseball-field-shooting-as-domestic-terror

Revising slightly downward due to passage of time. It appears (I say hesitantly) that right-wing activity has died down. The Proud Boys have significantly reduced their activity, and investigation/charging of a lot of people involved in the Capitol storming seems to have scared potential copycats off (in addition to jailing a number of people who were probably more at-risk to carry this type of attack out). My original thesis had the right (QAnon, Stop the Steal, anti-maskers, white supremacists) as the most likely to carry out these kinds of attacks. I'm not quite willing to revise downward due to their current quiet, since I'm worried about the opening-up as COVID winds down and the summer starts. There's a chance that the storming just caused a short-term quiet while everyone figured out what was going on and re-organized for the summer/fall.

This seems very hard to parse given the requirement under B of the Cornell link and the inherent subjectivity. If we go with, appearing on wikipedia page https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_terrorism#History_and_examples , then only 6 events qualify since 2000: Beltway sniper
2009 Fort hood shooting
2015 San Bernadino attack
Orlando Night Club shooting
Pittsburch synagogue shooting
El Paso shooting So if you go over the last 20-years you get a baseline of 30% for a full year or 16% for the half year or so we have left, and if you look over the last 10-years, it is more like 40% and 22% for the half year we have left.  Feels like I was too low before and going to adjust to the 22% the above analysis would imply as the "base rate" for the last 10-years

So it looked like this already happened in March 2021, but the motive didn't satisfy the definition of 'act of domestic terrorism' (motive was 'in response to Islamaphobic bullying', rather than ~'support for Al Qaeda'.). I'd say there is still a chance of later investigation concluding that it satisfies the technical definition of 'domestic terrorism' or of being prosecuted as such, which I'll estimate that as 5%.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Boulder_shooting Note: Fewer than 10 people died on the January 6th protests/entry, so I'm ignoring that entirely. Academic study says 41% of mass shootings satisfy all criteria of 'domestic terrorism', so I would reduce this question to '41% x the likelihood of a mass shooting in the remaining 7.5 months in 2021'. I would normally use a exponential distribution (mean = 11 months between mass shootings) to do this, but the re-opening of economy post-lockdown makes me thing that the normal distribution is no longer representative. Ignoring lockdown = 0.41 * .5057 which I'll cut in half due to lockdown and call ~10%.
https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/19434472.2020.1762108?journalCode=rirt20 Add my 10% + 5% = 15% estimate.
Moving down. While political rhetoric is still out there, it has calmed down as far as inciting violence. However, it only takes one person and there are a lot of crazies in the world.
I'll follow a formula of 55% discounted by 5% a month of this year.

In the last 10 years, there have been 4 attacks with greater than 10 fatalities, for a rate of 0.4 pa [1]
(San Bernardino, Orlando, Pittsburgh, El Paso)
There is 67% of the year left, multiplying 0.4 * 67% = 27%
I don't have a compelling argument either way as to why the current environment is better of worse than the preceding 10 years, so no adjustment up or down [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrorism_in_the_United_States#2010%E2%80%9319

With so many shootings, some of them will probably reach 10+ casualties. It's enough that one gets branded domestic terrorism. However, what media says and what the law says might diverge, though for public appearances, the two might converge. Especially if the attack is brutal enough.

decreasing forecast to reflect passing time, though mass casualty events in the US remain sadly frequent.

In my opinion question is, how many that kind of incidents there are. I would suggest three or four.

Thinking about the issue from a different perspective, how hard is to kill 10 people at once (or nearly together)?  Knives would be very difficult, as would handguns.  The minimum might be automatic weapons (machine guns, bump stock rigged rifles), or explosives, but explosive are harder than it might seem (former Combat Engineer experience), and difficult to target.  Automatic weapons are most likely if an individual intends such an event, but how easy is it to find (undetected) an automatic weapon, plus ammo and misc accoutrements.  Bottom line, this is not easy to kill 10 people together.
In Indianapolis, a mass-fatality shooting at a FedEx facility, by - if early reports are accurate - a current or former employee of FedEx.

Took the base rate of @nadie708 (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1232017): 35 % 9 months left : 0.35 * (9/12) = 0.26 Since tensions are high and weapons are everywhere, I would double or triple this base rate.

The 35% odds seem really crazy high. Unless somebody has done something like express support of ISIS or whatever, one big indicator I have noticed is whether the shooter leaves a manifesto.  The El Paso Walmart Shooter's manifesto is here for example: https://drudgereport.com/flashtx.htm  The Colorado King Soopers shooter for example did not leave a manifesto. It was a horrific crime, but it did not fit the strict criteria for an "act of domestic terrorism." List of mass shootings here:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mass_shootings_in_the_United_States_in_2021 You'll notice there have been 126 so far this year. 
Here was the latest notable one: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_Rock_Hill_shooting
These are horrific, but they are also a daily reality and it doesn't mean there is a 35% chance of being an "act of domestic terrorism" in the 38 weeks remaining in 2021.
Mass shootings are common but mass casualty situations are less so.

Boulder shooting is an act of domestic terrorism.

the federal statute by which this question will be adjudicated reads: (5)the term “domestic terrorism” means activities that—
(A)involve acts dangerous to human life that are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of any State;
(B)appear to be intended—
(i)to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
(ii)to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
(iii)to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping; and
(C)occur primarily within the territorial jurisdiction of the United States; and On 22 Mar 2021 there was a mass shooting in Boulder Colorado that resulted in 10 fatalities. https://edition.cnn.com/2021/03/22/us/boulder-colorado-shooting/index.html  On 23 Mar the shooter was identified as 21-year-old Al Aliwi Alissa. A motive is not yet known or disclosed. https://edition.cnn.com/2021/03/23/us/boulder-colorado-shooting-tuesday/index.html Initial reports suggest the man is of muslim heritage, lived "most" of his life inside the US since emigrating from Syria in 2002, has not expressed particularly strong religious or political views, and has exhibited signs of paranoia since 2014. I am personally fuzzy on the details but if his motivation was simply to kill people and not for any ideology, I think this case will not be prosecuted as domestic terrorism. Can anyone with more knowledge weigh in? Given this event meets at least half the criteria already, with the possibility of more information to come, I am upping my forecast from 45 -> 55%.
I admit, I'm guessing at this point.

Looks like the Colorado shootings are being attributed to "mental illness." The shooter has an Arab name, but being unfamiliar with Arab naming conventions, I suppose could be a Christian or perhaps a member of one of the syncretic religions, like a Druze or an Alawite. In any case, he does not appear to be "right-wing." "anti-government" or "white supremacist." In a related connection, from the links that GJO provides above to offer guidance in forecasting this question, I doubt if Islamic-inspired terrorism would close this question as a "yes" regardless of the casualty count. The DHS document linked above distinguishes between "Domestic Violent Extremists (DVEs)... motivated by a range of issues, including anger over COVID-19 restrictions, the 2020 election results, and police use of force..." and "Homegrown Violent Extremists (HVEs) inspired by foreign terrorist groups..." It seems to me that Islamic terrorists would fit into the latter category, and thus not be "Domestic Violent Extremists."

Will go up a little but I still think the crowd is incorrect here with this probability spike. A lot of this is actually a Rorschach test. Was the perpetrator primarily motivated by wanting to change government policies and coerce a civilian population, or was he an unhinged psychopath who had a high-capacity firearm?  Usually it ends up being interpreted as the latter, though sometimes it can be a bit fuzzy, as in the case of the Dayton shootings: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Dayton_shooting This is not a political site and I want to be careful to avoid politics, but it is important to point out the objective fact that mass shootings happen all the time in the United States, and you just don't hear about most of them. Please see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_mass_shootings_in_the_United_States_in_2021  The Boulder shooting was actually the 30th mass shooting this month. With respect to motive, none has been definitively established as yet: 
https://wfxl.com/news/nation-world/colorado-shooting-leaves-10-dead-in-latest-mass-tragedy However, "The suspect’s family told investigators they believed Alissa was suffering some type of mental illness, including delusions." Domestic terrorism is therefore  unlikely.
Risk is elevated far above baseline, but could decrease or increase depending on number of different factors -- mainly gov actions (especially regarding issues like COVID-19, firearms)
Increasing back to my previous forecast in case the answer's not closed - this was where I was before reducing for time remaining.

Using Wikipedia. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrorism_in_the_United_States Between 1970 and 2017 there have been 2,872 terrorist incidents that caused a total of 3,781 deaths. This means the average terrorist attack resulted in 1.32 deaths. Taking out 2001 from the sample gives an average of 0.27 deaths per attack. There have been 7 terrorist attacks which exceeded 10 deaths since 2000.  September 11 attacks (2001). 3008 died. 
Beltway sniper attacks (2002). 17 died. 
Fort Hood shooting (2009). 13 died. 
San Bernardino shooting (2015). 14 died. 
Orlando nightclub shooting (2016). 49 died.
Pittsburgh synagogue shooting (2018). 11 died. 
El Paso Walmart shooting (2019). 23 died.  Close to 10:
Charleston church shooting (2015). 9 died. 
New York City truck attack (2017). 8 died.  Therefore, 7/20 = 35% chance in any given year.  Since 2013 there has been a substantial increase in the number of terrorist incidences. This trend looks to be continuing.

Based on the Global Terrorism Database (GTD) for the US from 2001 (immediately after 9/11) to December 2018 we see 496 terrorist attacks. The mean number of fatalities is 0.73, primarily because 407 (82%) of the attacks had no fatalities. Excluding those, we have a mean of 4.07 fatalities with 9 out of 89 attacks (10%) including 10 or more fatalities. 9 out of 363 is 2.47% attacks with more than 10 fatalities. I then turned to the perpetrator groups for these 9 attacks: 3 x Jihadist-inspired extremist
1 x Anti-Semitic extremist
1 x Neo-Nazi extremist (suspected)
1 x White Supremacist/Nationalist
1 x Anti-Government Extremists
1 x Incel Extremist
1 x Unknown (this was the bombing of the West Fertilizer Company plant in West, Texas) The earliest attack in the database is November 5, 2009. The next attack was 1259 days away, but the trend is that attacks are happening sooner over time: 699, 558, 553, 290, 351, 367, 324. There are 261 days left in the year. The shortest gap between two attacks claiming over 10 lives is 290 days. Although the chance of an attack is remote, I'm going to keep my 3% probability and adjust down as we get further into the year.

All my base rate data comes from wikipedia at this point and I have not verified that all of the domestic terrorism incidents they count actually meet the legal criteria as defined in this question. however:

since 1900 there have been 181 domestic terror incidents 17 with 10+ fatalities so that is about 1.5 incidents a year, since 10% of incidents have 10+ fatalities that is about at 14% chance that there will be an incident in any given year that has 10+ fatalities.  If you want to narrow the base to more recent years to eliminate possible confounding variables tied to specific historical periods then there are 93 incidents since 2000, 7 of which have cause 10+ fatalities   this base rate gives you 4.65 incidents per year 7.5% of which cause 10+ fatalities so roughly 35% chance that there will be an incident w/ 10+ fatalities in any given year.  It looks like rate of domestic terrorism has increased since half of the cases in the last 120 years occurred in the last 20 years, so I'm going to err toward the second base rate. Also from Wikipedia the center for investigative reporting apparently did a study of cases between 2008 nd 2016 and found that right wing groups accounted for 58% of incidents, had 35% chance of being stopped by authorities and 29% chance of creating casualties.  radical islamist groups accounted for 32% of incidents, had 76% chance of being stopped and 13% chance of causing fatalities. Left wing groups accounted for the remaining 10% of incidents, had 20% chance of getting stopped and 10% chance of causing casualties.  This data doesn't account for the increased reporting on right wing groups since 2016. and I haven't gone through it for causation but it looks like right wing groups are the most likely to cause casualties and are unlikely to be stopped. This may have changed in the wake of this year's incident since law enforcement is now specifically looking for right wing threats. I'm also going to consider that terrorism is a political act so labeling an incident as terrorism is a political statement, so context matters a whole lot in whether a particular incident is labeled in this way especially at the time it happens. I'm unsure which way the political winds are going to blow on this one yet. will have a better feel as the year progresses.

Since 2015 there have been four domestic terrorist attacks in the United States that have resulted in at least 10 fatalities with the last event occurring in 2019 [1]. After the insurrection at the US capitol was perpetrated by right-wing extremists on 6 Jan 2021, Democrats vowed to make domestic terrorism a top priority of their legislative agenda [2]. Additionally, analysis has shown that a rise in right-wing extremism would be the most likely source of domestic terror attacks in the US over the next three to five years [3]. Due to the increased government attention on domestic terrorism due to the insurrection at the US capitol, I do not expect a major domestic terror attack to take place in the United States during the timeframe of this question. Additionally, with multiple schools closed, and many public activities shut down throughout the country (including large-scale gatherings at sports events and most churches) for at least the first half of 2021, the opportunities for a mass casualty domestic terrorist event are more limited than they would be otherwise. Thus, I predict a 1% probability that a domestic terrorist attack, with 10 fatalities, will occur in the US before 1 January 2022. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrorism_in_the_United_States#2020%E2%80%93present
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/01/14/trailer-how-democrats-plan-fight-domestic-terror/
[3] https://www.csis.org/analysis/escalating-terrorism-problem-united-states

When you look at trends of domestic terror attacks in the US within the past twenty to thirty years, you will see that there has been a surge in activity deemed domestic acts of terror and the frequency of their occurrence; Many factors can contribute to this increase, but the estimation here is only in regards to whether an act which qualifies as domestic terror will claim ten or more victims by Jan 1, 2022. As another user pointed out, there have been seven officially recognized domestic terror incidents since 2000 which meet this criteria according to the most readily available source, which is the Wikipedia entry for domestic terror in the US; A notable omission from this list was the Las Vegas strip shootings in 2017, which should be labeled domestic terror. Including this incident gives me approximately eight acts within the past 20± years which meet the above criteria, and which results in approximately 40% chance of such an act occurring within any given year during that period based on the total incidents. Given a time adjustment of about 4.1% as we are forty-one days into year 2021, we now have a remaining percentage of approximately 35.9%. Other considerations should be made for the strategy adjustments made by security personnel and intelligence agency personnel tasked with thwarting domestic terror threats, as it can be reasonably assumed that the current state of overall security forces are rather heightened and sensitive to any potential domestic terror threats after the DC riots. It would be reasonable to expect that this presence will lead to a reduction the probability of an act occurring in the the short-term, and as such, I would estimate that this decreases the odds of a domestic act of terror occurring by about 20% (or a one-in-five chance), leaving us with a 15.9% probability of occurrence that within the next year and act will occur which satisfies the criteria of this question.

I'm back.  Nasty password fiasco whipped out a fair amount of my hard drive , including my previous forecasts.  This will be 'off the cuff', with a considered assessment, BUT, here's a quick starter.. Despite the fears of international terrorist plots in the United States associated with Millennium celebrations, domestic special-interest or single-issue domestic terrorists committed 8 of the 10 terrorist incidents recorded in the United States during the calendar year; the remaining two incidents were perpetrated by rogue right-wing extremists. These 10 incidents doubled the number of terrorist incidents recorded the previous year. Six terrorist incidents in 1999 were attributed to an extremist movement known as the Animal Liberation Front (ALF). Combined, these attacks resulted in financial damages (primarily to medical research facilities) of more than three million dollars. Two acts of terrorism were attributed to a distinct but related movement known as the Earth Liberation Front (ELF). These attacks resulted in the complete destruction of an 8,000-square-foot office complex in Monmouth, Ore., and one million dollars in damage to the Agricultural Hall at Michigan State University. None of the incidents resulted in human casualties. For the sixth consecutive year, there were no successful acts of international terrorism perpetrated in the United States in 1999. An overview of international terrorism over the last three decades has been the most destructive in history. Over 14,000 international terrorist attacks have occurred worldwide since 1968. These attacks have resulted in more than 10,000 deaths. Between 1980 and 1999, the FBI recorded 327 incidents or suspected incidents of terrorism in the United States. Of these, 239 were attributed to domestic terrorists, and 88 were determined to be international. Combined, these acts resulted in the deaths of 205 persons and in the injury of over 2,037. Although the United States and the world now experience fewer acts of terrorism when compared to figures from the 1970's and 1980's, a troubling trend toward more destructive attacks has tempered this positive development. U.S. intelligence and law enforcement communities have developed an effective and highly integrated response to the challenge of terrorism. As the lead agency in the fight against terrorism in the United States, the highest priority of the FBI's Counterterrorism Program is to prevent acts of terrorism from occurring, but when acts do occur, the FBI mounts aggressive investigations to identify and apprehend the perpetrators. Increasingly, the FBI's efforts involve the assistance and cooperation of other intelligence and law enforcement agencies. Appendixes summarize terrorist incidents in the United States during the past decade and provide background information on currently designated foreign terrorist organizations and terrorist activities (1987-99), as well as a series of graphs that depict terrorist-related activity in the United States during the past two decades.

Since 1995, there have only been a handful of domestic terrorist attacks in the US - numbering only about 10-15. However, they have been increasing in frequency with a peak in 2015 (Charleston Church, San Bernardino, Orlando). Notably, only four of these have resulted in 10 or more fatalities (Oklahoma, Orlando, Pittsburgh, El Paso Walmart).  The center for strategic & international studies reports that the majority of domestic terrorism incidents, as well as deaths, in the US are a result of  right-wing attacks (https://www.csis.org/analysis/escalating-terrorism-problem-united-states) and that these are increasing in quantity. As such, with a centrist/leftist in office in Biden, it is likely that right-wing attacks are more likely. Further, the arrival of conspiracy theories such as QAnon are also likely to increase the risk of such an attack. However, while the risk may be elevated, the base probability is nonetheless low. We are also a month and a half into 2021 already, so there's less than a full year left.

The first thing I start with is the base rate. In the past 100 months, there have been the following incidents I could find that would have triggered a Yes outcome:
1) August 2019: El Paso Walmart. (There was also the Dayton shooting that month, but it's unclear whether it was intended to influence government policy or action.)
2) October 2018: Pittsburgh synagogue
3)  June 2016 Orlando Pulse nightclub
4) December 2015 San Bernadino attack That gets us to 4% a month. Averaged over the 10 months remaining, (0.96 to the tenth power) that means 33%.  However, with more attention in general focused on the issue -- not just law enforcement, but lots of little things, like websites doing a better job policing their users for illegal activities --  you can probably bump it down to 20%.

Recent history and current inflamed tensions would seem to argue for a relatively high probability - last 5 years would appear to get you to a 40% probability and arguably tensions are higher now. However realistically I think a longer view would give a better base at something a bit below 10%. Actually think tensions will fall a bit so going with 7%. Crowd at 5% seems a little low given unfortunately the casualty figure is not that high in a very armed society.

As @hoosier2020 notes, acts of domestic terrorism, as defined by the Cornell citation, that result in 10 deaths or more are quite infrequent.  Only seven in the last 50 years, making for a seven percent chance each decade.  The fact that the FBI and DHS are on high alert to White Supremacist plotting is to me a hopeful sign that they are monitoring known threats, making it less likely that those attacks will eventuate.  Covid also makes it more difficult to find venues with large crowds for attacks.  That will change as the year progresses, but genuine terrorist attacks are usually the result of careful planning and rehearsals, all of which take many months. On the down side, the frequency of these sorts of attacks has accelerated.  Six of the seven have happened in the last 25 years and five of seven have occurred in the last 18 years, making a 3.6% chance each year.  Also complicating matters is the decision by social media companies to de-platform White Supremacists groups, making the job of the FBI in monitoring their activities on-line much more difficult as the far-right groups turn to encrypted apps to communicate.[1]  We begin to venture into the territory of unknown unknowns.  Given the far-right's anti-vaccine culture, among the few places likely to have lots of people will be mass vaccination sites, providing them with a target-rich environment of people who they would consider "The Other" given their willingness to be vaccinated. A serious attempt on January 6, 2022 would not be a surprise, in my estimate, as the far-right seeks commemoration and retribution for the anniversary of the date on which they believe the U.S. election was stolen from the previous president.  Far-right groups, like their Islamic counterparts, do like the symbolism of launching attacks on dates important to their causes and movement.  For example, Timothy McVeigh's choice of the day for his attack in Oklahoma was designed to commemorate the fiery end and destruction of the Waco, Texas siege of the Branch Davidians.[2]  An attack on January 6, 2022 is beyond the terms of reference of this question, however.

[1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/far-right-investigations-encrypted-fbi/2021/01/17/bd7a71ac-580a-11eb-a931-5b162d0d033d_story.html
[2] https://www.cnn.com/2013/09/18/us/oklahoma-city-bombing-fast-facts/index.html

Interesting question. I assume the perpetrator(s) must actually identify their motive, or a pattern of behavior that can be construed as constituting a motive (as in the El Paso, or Oklahoma City, or Pittsburgh massacres). However, I note that the Cornell definition is: (5) the term “domestic terrorism” means activities that—
(A) involve acts dangerous to human life that are a violation of the criminal laws of the United States or of any State;
(B) appear to be intended—
(i) to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;
(ii) to influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion; or
(iii) to affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction, assassination, or kidnapping; and... Clause (B) stipulates that the act only has to have the *appearance* of domestic terrorism. As the explanation of this question hints, more than one person in the press or government characterized the Capitol riot was an instance of "domestic terrorism" by a large number of people including President Biden. It seems like it falls under the Cornell definition because the mob intended to "influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion;" that is, stop the certification of the electoral college votes. The fact that they had no hope of doing this, is I suppose, not relevant to their conformity with the Cornell definition. But is it relevant to whether they are terrorists? Not to put too fine a point on it, were they just a bunch of idiots LARPing a revolution? The riots that occurred over the summer in several cities were not domestic terrorism, evidently, even though they arguably "intend[ed] to intimidate or coerce a civilian population;" "influence the policy of a government by intimidation or coercion;" and "affect the conduct of a government by mass destruction..." Nobody called the rioters terrorists, because they weren't. They were rioters.  So this isn't a question about actions, it's a question of how actions are spun. When are rioters violent yahoos whose actions sometimes wind up causing fatalities, and always wind up causing destruction? Because we've seen plenty of that this year. And when are rioters "terrorists?" I guess we'll find out. Nevertheless, my forecast is that the chance is zero. Links:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/biden-says-mob-that-stormed-capitol-were-domestic-terrorists-11610046962 https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2021/02/05/fighting-domestic-terrorism-after-violence-capitol-riots-column/4372366001/ https://thehill.com/homenews/house/534001-scalise-labels-capitol-rioting-domestic-terrorism

Since 2000 there have been 7 acts of domestic terrorism that have resulted in 10 or more fatalities. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrorism_in_the_United_States#2020%E2%80%93present) This gives me a base rate of 35% for the chance that there will be an act of domestic terrorism in the United States resulting in 10 or more fatalities in a given year. I will reduce this by 3% (roughly 1/12) since the month of January has already passed so I am now at 32%. I will reduce the forecast by another 5% to 27% due to some places of worship, restaurants, and nightclubs, which are frequent targets for acts of domestic terrorism, being closed for COVID-19. The heightened level of security in the United States likely makes it more difficult to plan and carry out an attack so I will further reduce my forecast by 8% to 19%. Lastly, I will slight increase my forecast by 3% given the increased chance of a domestic terrorist attack by a white supremacist group for a final forecast of 22%.
